Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: New Proteomic Strategy to Visualize and Analyze Phosphoproteomes
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry is supporting Professors Tao and Zhu at Purdue University to develop and implement a platform for identification and quantification of phosphoproteomes of interest. Reversible protein phosphorylation regulates a number of biological processes, such as onset of many diseases and plant signaling. While it has been found extensive, at any given time only a small percentage of phosphorylated proteins may change their phosphorylation status in response to a particular cellular event, which makes it extremely challenging for detection and quantitative measurement of phosphorylated proteins of relevant. The proposed proteomic platform aims at a versatile and cost-effective analytical tool. The technique will be applied to identify important phosphoproteins involved in osmosis, water, temperature, cold, and nutrient deficiency stress in Arabidopsis. In addition to providing interdisciplinary learning experience to both graduate and undergraduate students, the PIs also plan to promote teaching, training, learning, and discovery through the development of a new summer undergraduate lab course to engage students in a genuine research project that emphasizes the utilization of modern analytical methods and to enhance students' academic opportunities.

The project will develop a novel proteomic platform that addresses two major analytical questions related to large-scale protein phosphorylation analyses: how to quantitatively visualize and detect phosphorylated proteins in a complex sample and how to identify phosphoproteins of interest and their sites of phosphorylation. The core of the platform is novel chemical reagents that are multi-functionalized for high specificity and selectivity toward phosphoproteins in complex biological samples such as whole cell extracts. The platform will allow for the selection of phosphoproteins of interest that are further subjected to tandem mass spectrometry to get sequencing information and sites of phosphorylation. The technique seeks to provide researchers with a useful technique for routine phosphorylation analyses. Major applications include quantitative measurement of phosphorylation, assays of kinase and phosphatase activity, screening for kinase/phosphatase inhibition, and detection of in vivo phosphorylation in different cellular states.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Final outcomes

Protein modifications have been linked to a majority of important cellular functions and diseases.  Protein phosphorylation is one the most ubiquitous modifications. For example, it is crucial for plant cells in perceiving and responding to environmental stimuli such as cold and insect stresses. Measuring the phosphorylation status of an individual protein or classes of proteins has become a routine but extremely important step in a wide range of research disciplines. Mass spectrometry (MS) has been the major technology for identifying thousands of phosphorylation sites in a single experiment. However, significantly analytical difficulty is encountered in complex biological samples such as plant extracts due to the high dynamic range of proteome, toughness of plant cell walls, and potential interference from chlorophyll and secondary metabolites. These challenges make it hard to detect important phosphorylation events. Current phosphoproteomics analysis is ineffective and cost-prohibitive for many studies. Despite a number of large-scale phosphoproteomic studies, there is a critical need for a routine and effective analysis of relevant phosphoproteins.

This NSF-funded project attempts to develop and implement a sustainable platform for robust and reproducible analysis of phosphoproteomes in complex biological samples. In the first outcome, we have streamlined a plant sample preparation procedure tailored for plant phosphoproteomics, and then applied the pipeline to identify critical phosphorylation events involved in tomato cold tolerance mechanisms (Figure 1). Cold stress is a major environmental factor that affects the growth, distribution of plants, and determines the yield of many important crops grown in the world. We compared the phosphoproteomic change under cold stress of two tomatoes with distinctive cold tolerance phenotypes using high resolution mass spectrometry. We identified more than 5,000 phosphoproteins and 14,000 phosphorylation sites in tomato leaves, the largest tomato phosphoproteomic resource for studying tomato signaling changes.

In the second outcome, we developed a platform, termed differential gel electrophoresis of phosphoproteome (DiGEP), to differentially visualize phosphoproteins on a single gel, to facilitate targeted analysis by MS (Figure 2). Phosphoproteins are differentially labeled in high specificity using novel tri-functionalized reagents containing the Ti(IV) ion, fluorophore, and photoactive crosslinker for specific imaging and identification. This platform allowed for simple and efficient quantitative assessment of protein phosphorylation in high throughput in one single gel. Phosphoproteins that only show relevant changes were subjected to mass spectrometric analysis. The technique is fully compatible with gel systems and imaging software for Differential Gel Electrophoresis (DIGE). We compared the phosphoproteomic change under cold stress of two tomatoes with distinctive cold tolerance phenotypes and then identified phosphoproteins that responded to cold stress by targeted MS.
